awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites:  Type II - University of Minnesota Innovation Site
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, from the University of Minnesota - Twin Cities, extends this institution's NSF I-Corps Site for scale up to their next phase of support for innovation and entrepreneurship.

Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors. 

Since June 2014, the University of Minnesota (UMN) Innovation Corps (MIN-Corps) program provided infrastructure, resources, networking opportunities, training, and NSF-supported project funding to UMN students, faculty, and staff pursuing commercialization. As of December 31, 2017, MIN-Corps had hosted over 1,000 participants - more than half of whom were women - in its courses, seminars, or outreach events. Over 180 innovation teams trained with MIN-Corps, leading to seven participants in the national I-Corps Teams program, 12 licenses of UMN intellectual property, and a dozen startups and other continuing projects that have received over $8 million in commercialization grants and/or investor funding. 

The primary goals for the next funding cycle are to increase the quantity and quality of technology commercialization across UMN, increase program participation and commercialization activity by women and under-represented minorities, extend programming to UMN campuses in under-resourced communities outside the Twin Cities, and contribute to the vitality of the Midwest and national technology entrepreneurship and commercialization ecosystem.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
Over the duration of the Type II grant, MIN-Corps at the University of Minnesota (UMN) offered a total of 82 Lean LaunchPad courses and seminars to 2,259 participants belonging to 586 teams.  We also delivered 27 Innovator Engagement events to 2,208 participants.  Lean Launch Pad courses included STARTUP (a 2-credit course offered each fall and spring), Value Proposition Design Workshops and Webinars (noncredit Lean LaunchPad short course), incorporation of Lean LaunchPad concepts and assignments into engineering senior design courses, and other programs tailored to specific audiences (especially the Inclusive Innovators Network for innovators from under-represented genders/races/ethnicities and the MVP Challenge prototyping program). Innovator engagement events included mentor connections, mixers and the annual Women Innovators Conference, which contributed to increasing female participation In I-Corps-style programs from 36% to 52%. 

23 University of Minnesota teams participated in national I-Corps Teams cohorts between fall 2018 and spring 2022.  Approximately 30% of the technologies in the 2018-2022 Office for Technology Commercialization Venture Center startup pipeline participated in MIN-Corps and/or regional I-Corps programs.  In addition, MIN-Corps alumni launched 23 startups in 2018-2022 (total of 38 since MIN-Corps started in 2014); were awarded 22 SBIR, STTR and PFI grants Fall 2018 – Spring 2022 (total of 27 grants since the MIN-Corps site started in 2014); and attracted $31 million of commercialization grants and investment funding in 2018-2022 (total of over $42 million since 2014).

MIN-Corps’ impact extended across the University and state of Minnesota.  For instance, ATP-Bio, a Gen-4 NSF Engineering Research Center, was launched in 2020 with the I-Corps methodology as a component of its Innovation Ecosystem Pillar to train researchers on commercialization. In addition, since July 2021, the I-Corps methodology has been incorporated into the Innovation Pillar of UMN’s Institute for Engineering in Medicine, including the Innovation Fellows training program in the Bakken Medical Devices Center.  Beginning in Spring 2020, the State of Minnesota entrepreneurship program, Launch Minnesota, contracted with the University of Minnesota to offer the remote MIN-Corps Lean LaunchPad short course to science/tech entrepreneurs across the state.  273 entrepreneurs in 8 cohorts have participated so far.

At the regional level. the University of Minnesota provided its online pedagogic expertise to the Midwest I-Corps Node to adapt the MIN-Corps Value Proposition course to become the basis of the MWIN “Jumpstart” flagship Lean LaunchPad remote short course. We also provided content and production expertise to MWIN regarding development of a platform technology assessment workshop.  These collaborations led to UMN joining the MWIN core institutions for a successful I-Corps Hubs proposal.  The University of Minnesota is now an I-Corps Great Lakes Region Hub as a partner as of January 1, 2022.

 


Last Modified: 06/17/2022
Modified by: Mostafa Kaveh

We also delivered 27 Innovator Engagement events to 2,208 participants.  Lean Launch Pad courses included STARTUP (a 2-credit course offered each fall and spring), Value Proposition Design Workshops and Webinars (noncredit Lean LaunchPad short course), incorporation of Lean LaunchPad concepts and assignments into engineering senior design courses, and other programs tailored to specific audiences (especially the Inclusive Innovators Network for innovators from under-represented genders/races/ethnicities and the MVP Challenge prototyping program). Innovator engagement events included mentor connections, mixers and the annual Women Innovators Conference, which contributed to increasing female participation In I-Corps-style programs from 36% to 52%. 

23 University of Minnesota teams participated in national I-Corps Teams cohorts between fall 2018 and spring 2022.  Approximately 30% of the technologies in the 2018-2022 Office for Technology Commercialization Venture Center startup pipeline participated in MIN-Corps and/or regional I-Corps programs. In addition, since July 2021, the I-Corps methodology has been incorporated into the Innovation Pillar of UMN’s Institute for Engineering in Medicine, including the Innovation Fellows training program in the Bakken Medical Devices Center.
